  physical_appearance: This is a mandarin-collar top. It is gray in colour. The buttons run from the collar and sideways
 towards the left. The sleeves are mid-length. The hem of the top flares outwards slightly. The fabric features light woven stripes creating a diamond pattern. There are no tears seen on this garment.

 general) maids (servants) lozenges

 Earl Ming-Teh

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: This grey coloured mandarin-collar top with woven stripes belonged to a majie
 a Cantonese female domestic helper. Majie is derived from a Shun Tak term (ma cheh) which means mother and sister. As this group of women had taken a vow never to marry
 the term Majie alludes to their spinsterhood and refers to their work taking care of children. Majies typically wore a samfoo uniform consisting of a white mandarin-collar top and black trousers.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a mandarin-collar top. It is gray in colour. The buttons run from the collar and sideways, towards the left. The sleeves are mid-length. The hem of the top flares outwards slightly. The fabric features light woven stripes creating a diamond pattern. There are no tears seen on this garment.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This grey coloured mandarin-collar top with woven stripes belonged to a majie, a Cantonese female domestic helper. Majie is derived from a Shun Tak term (ma cheh) which means mother and sister. As this group of women had taken a vow never to marry, the term Majie alludes to their spinsterhood and refers to their work taking care of children. Majies typically wore a samfoo uniform consisting of a white mandarin-collar top and black trousers.
